3.26.text:
Endeth here the fifth day of the Decameron,
beginneth the sixth, wherein, under the rule

11.41.text:
of Elisa, discourse is had of such as by some
sprightly sally have repulsed an attack, or

17.86.text:
by some ready retort or device have avoided
loss, peril or scorn.

23.46.text:
Still in mid heaven, the moon had lost her
radiance, nor was any part of our world unillumined

30.33.text:
by the fresh splendour of the dawn, when,
the queen being risen and having mustered

35.58.text:
her company, they hied them, gently sauntering,
across the dewy mead some distance from the

41.36.text:
beautiful hill, conversing now of this, now
of the other matter, canvassing the stories,

47.34.text:
their greater or less degree of beauty, and
laughing afresh at divers of their incidents,

53.90.text:
until, the sun being now in his higher ascendant,
they began to feel his heat, and turning back

60.35.text:
by common consent, retraced their steps to
the palace, where, the tables being already

66.15.text:
set, and fragrant herbs and fair flowers strewn
all about, they by the queen's command, before

72.52.text:
it should grow hotter, addressed themselves
to their meal. So, having blithely breakfasted,

78.02.text:
they first of all sang some dainty and jocund
ditties, and then, as they were severally

83.78.text:
minded, composed them to sleep or sat them
down to chess or dice, while Dioneo and Lauretta

90.11.text: fell a singing of Troilus and Cressida.

94.52.text:
The hour of session being come, they took
their places, at the queen's summons, in their

99.77.text:
wonted order by the fountain; but, when the
queen was about to call for the first story,

105.55.text:
that happened which had not happened before;
to wit, there being a great uproar in the

111.22.text:
kitchen among the maids and men, the sound
thereof reached the ears of the queen and

116.15.text:
all the company. Whereupon the queen called
the seneschal and asked him who bawled so

121.99.text:
loud, and what was the occasion of the uproar.
The seneschal made answer that 'twas some

127.71.text:
contention between Licisca and Tindaro; but
the occasion he knew not, having but just

133.56.text:
come to quiet them, when he received her summons.
The queen then bade him cause Licisca and

139.96.text:
Tindaro to come thither forthwith: so they
came, and the queen enquired of them the cause

146.15.text:
of the uproar. Tindaro was about to make answer,
when Licisca, who was somewhat advanced in

152.66.text:
years, and disposed to give herself airs,
and heated to the strife of words, turned

157.98.text:
to Tindaro, and scowling upon him said: "Unmannerly
varlet that makest bold to speak before me;

164.40.text:
leave me to tell the story." Then, turning
to the queen, she said: "Madam, this fellow

171.30.text:
would fain instruct me as to Sicofante's wife,
and—neither more or less—as if I had not

177.10.text:
known her well—would have me believe that,
the first night that Sicofante lay with her,

183.33.text:
'twas by force and not without effusion of
blood that Master Yard made his way into Dusky

188.80.text:
Hill; which I deny, averring that he met with
no resistance, but, on the contrary, with

195.24.text:
a hearty welcome on the part of the garrison.
And such a numskull is he as fondly to believe

201.88.text:
that the girls are so simple as to let slip
their opportunities, while they wait on the

208.31.text:
caprice of father or brothers, who six times
out of seven delay to marry them for three

212.17.text:
or four years after they should. Ay, ay indeed,
doubtless they were well advised to tarry

218.47.text:
so long! Christ's faith! I should know the
truth of what I swear; there is never a woman

224.19.text:
in my neighbour-hood whose husband had her
virginity; and well I know how many and what

229.49.text:
manner of tricks our married dames play their
husbands; and yet this booby would fain teach

235.62.text: me to know women as if I were but born yesterday."

240.29.text:
While Licisca thus spoke, the ladies laughed
till all their teeth were ready to start from

245.33.text:
their heads. Six times at least the queen
bade her be silent: but all in vain; she halted

252.31.text:
not till she had said all that she had a mind
to. When she had done, the queen turned with

257.56.text:
a smile to Dioneo saying: "This is a question
for thee to deal with, Dioneo; so hold thyself

264.92.text:
in readiness to give final judgment upon it,
when our stories are ended." "Madam," replied

270.84.text:
Dioneo forthwith, "I give judgment without
more ado: I say that Licisca is in the right;

276.92.text:
I believe that 'tis even as she says, and
that Tindaro is a fool." Whereupon Licisca

283.72.text:
burst out laughing, and turning to Tindaro:
"Now did I not tell thee so?" quoth she. "Begone

291.35.text:
in God's name: dost think to know more than
I, thou that art but a sucking babe? Thank

297.31.text:
God, I have not lived for nothing, not I."
And had not the queen sternly bade her be

303.68.text:
silent, and make no more disturbance, unless
she had a mind to be whipped, and sent both

309.60.text:
her and Tindaro back to the kitchen, the whole
day would have been spent in nought but listening

314.96.text:
to her. So Licisca and Tindaro having withdrawn,
the queen charged Filomena to tell the first

321.92.text: story: and gaily thus Filomena began.

326.35.text: End of Day Six, The Introduction

333.62.text:
A knight offers to carry Madonna Oretta a
horseback with a story, but tells it so ill

341.08.text: that she prays him to dismount her.

343.07.text:
As stars are set for an ornament in the serene
expanse of heaven, and likewise in springtime

349.78.text:
flowers and leafy shrubs in the green meadows,
so, damsels, in the hour of rare and excellent

356.03.text:
discourse, is wit with its bright sallies.
Which, being brief, are much more proper for

362.22.text:
ladies than for men, seeing that prolixity
of speech, where brevity is possible, is much

368.68.text:
less allowable to them. But for whatever cause,
be it the sorry quality of our understanding,

375.53.text:
or some especial enmity that heaven bears
to our generation, few ladies or none are

380.91.text:
left to-day that, when occasion prompts, are
able to meet it with apt speech, ay, or if

387.53.text:
aught of the kind they hear, can understand
it aright: to our common shame be it spoken!

395.24.text:
But as, touching this matter, enough has already
been said by Pampinea, I purpose not to enlarge

402.24.text:
thereon; but, that you may know what excellence
resides in speech apt for the occasion, I

407.83.text:
am minded to tell you after how courteous
a fashion a lady imposed silence upon a gentleman.

414.94.text:
'Tis no long time since there dwelt in our
city a lady, noble, debonair and of excellent

421.06.text:
discourse, whom not a few of you may have
seen or heard of, whose name—for such high

427.03.text:
qualities merit not oblivion—was Madonna
Oretta, her husband being Messer Geri Spina.

434.33.text:
Now this lady, happening to be, as we are,
in the country, moving from place to place

440.50.text:
for pleasure with a company of ladies and
gentlemen, whom she had entertained the day

446.12.text:
before at breakfast at her house, and the
place of their next sojourn, whither they

451.48.text:
were to go afoot, being some considerable
distance off, one of the gentlemen of the

457.09.text:
company said to her: "Madonna Oretta, so please
you, I will carry you great part of the way

463.03.text:
a horseback with one of the finest stories
in the world." "Indeed, Sir," replied the

469.27.text:
lady, "I pray you do so; and I shall deem
it the greatest of favours." Whereupon the

476.59.text:
gentleman, who perhaps was no better master
of his weapon than of his story, began a tale,

482.30.text:
which in itself was indeed excellent, but
which, by repeating the same word three, four

489.43.text:
or six times, and now and again harking back,
and saying: "I said not well"; and erring

496.63.text:
not seldom in the names, setting one in place
of another, he utterly spoiled; besides which,

502.70.text:
his mode of delivery accorded very ill with
the character of the persons and incidents:

509.46.text:
insomuch that Madonna Oretta, as she listened,
did oft sweat, and was like to faint, as if

516.15.text:
she were ill and at the point of death. And
being at length able to bear no more of it,

522.50.text:
witting that the gentleman had got into a
mess and was not like to get out of it, she

528.11.text:
said pleasantly to him: "Sir, this horse of
yours trots too hard; I pray you be pleased

534.14.text:
to set me down." The gentleman, being perchance
more quick of apprehension than he was skilful

540.21.text:
in narration, missed not the meaning of her
sally, and took it in all good and gay humour.

547.11.text:
So, leaving unfinished the tale which he had
begun, and so mishandled, he addressed himself

555.87.text: End of Day Six, The First Story

564.32.text:
Cisti, a baker, by an apt speech gives Messer
Geri Spina to know that he has by inadvertence

577.39.text: asked that of him which he should not.

580.20.text:
All the ladies and the men alike having greatly
commended Madonna Oretta's apt saying, the

586.95.text:
queen bade Pampinea follow suit, and thus
she began:

591.46.text:
Fair ladies, I cannot myself determine whether
Nature or Fortune be the more at fault, the

598.58.text:
one in furnishing a noble soul with a vile
body, or the other in allotting a base occupation

605.33.text:
to a body endowed with a noble soul, whereof
we may have seen an example, among others,

612.77.text:
in our fellow-citizen, Cisti; whom, furnished
though he was with a most lofty soul, Fortune

622.95.text:
made a baker. And verily I should curse Nature
and Fortune alike, did I not know that Nature

631.39.text:
is most discreet, and that Fortune, albeit
the foolish imagine her blind, has a thousand

640.66.text:
eyes. For 'tis, I suppose, that, being wise
above a little, they do as mortals ofttimes

650.31.text:
do, who, being uncertain as to their future,
provide against contingencies by burying their

658.52.text:
most precious treasures in the basest places
in their houses, as being the least likely

665.30.text:
to be suspected; whence, in the hour of their
greatest need, they bring them forth, the

673.69.text:
base place having kept them more safe than
the dainty chamber would have done. And so

681.96.text:
these two arbitresses of the world not seldom
hide their most precious commodities in the

687.05.text:
obscurity of the crafts that are reputed most
base, that thence being brought to light they

696.07.text:
may shine with a brighter splendour. Whereof
how in a trifling matter Cisti, the baker,

705.47.text:
gave proof, restoring the eyes of the mind
to Messer Geri Spina, whom the story of his

712.87.text:
wife, Madonna Oretta, has brought to my recollection,
I am minded to shew you in a narrative which

727.10.text:
I say then that Pope Boniface, with whom Messer
Geri Spina stood very high in favour and honour,

734.89.text:
having sent divers of his courtiers to Florence
as ambassadors to treat of certain matters

741.21.text:
of great moment, and they being lodged in
Messer Geri's house, where he treated with

748.55.text:
them of the said affairs of the Pope, 'twas,
for some reason or another, the wont of Messer

757.37.text:
Geri and the ambassadors of the Pope to pass
almost every morning by Santa Maria Ughi,

763.83.text:
where Cisti, the baker, had his bakehouse,
and plied his craft in person. Now, albeit

774.34.text:
Fortune had allotted him a very humble occupation,
she had nevertheless prospered him therein

781.41.text:
to such a degree that he was grown most wealthy,
and without ever aspiring to change it for

787.91.text:
another, lived in most magnificent style,
having among his other good things a cellar

794.64.text:
of the best wines, white and red, that were
to be found in Florence, or the country parts;

802.44.text:
and marking Messer Geri and the ambassadors
of the Pope pass every morning by his door,

808.13.text:
he bethought him that, as 'twas very hot,
'twould be a very courteous thing to give

814.17.text:
them to drink of his good wine; but comparing
his rank with that of Messer Geri, he deemed

821.81.text:
it unseemly to presume to invite him, and
cast about how he might lead Messer Geri to

828.74.text:
invite himself. So, wearing always the whitest
of doublets and a spotless apron, that denoted

838.97.text:
rather the miller than the baker, he let bring,
every morning about the hour that he expected

845.52.text:
Messer Geri and the ambassadors to pass by
his door, a spick-and-span bucket of fresh

852.74.text:
and cool spring water, and a small Bolognese
flagon of his good white wine, and two beakers

861.91.text:
that shone like silver, so bright were they:
and there down he sat him, as they came by,

873.13.text:
and after hawking once or twice, fell a drinking
his wine with such gusto that 'twould have

880.50.text:
raised a thirst in a corpse. Which Messer
Geri having observed on two successive mornings,

889.29.text:
said on the third: "What is't, Cisti? Is't
good?" Whereupon Cisti jumped up, and answered:

899.67.text:
"Ay, Sir, good it is; but in what degree I
might by no means make you understand, unless

906.74.text:
you tasted it." Messer Geri, in whom either
the heat of the weather, or unwonted fatigue,

917.66.text:
or, perchance, the gusto with which he had
seen Cisti drink, had bred a thirst, turned

926.45.text:
to the ambassadors and said with a smile:
"Gentlemen, 'twere well to test the quality

932.69.text:
of this worthy man's wine: it may be such
that we shall not repent us." And so in a

942.18.text:
body they came up to where Cisti stood; who,
having caused a goodly bench to be brought

948.73.text:
out of the bakehouse, bade them be seated,
and to their servants, who were now coming

951.15.text:
forward to wash the beakers, said: "Stand
back, comrades, and leave this office to me,

956.02.text:
for I know as well how to serve wine as to
bake bread; and expect not to taste a drop

962.14.text:
yourselves." Which said, he washed four fine
new beakers with his own hands, and having

971.80.text:
sent for a small flagon of his good wine,
he heedfully filled the beakers, and presented

977.89.text:
them to Messer Geri and his companions; who
deemed the wine the best that they had drunk

985.00.text:
for a great while. So Messer Geri, having
praised the wine not a little, came there

992.45.text:
to drink every morning with the ambassadors
as long as they tarried with him.

999.85.text:
Now when the ambassadors had received their
congè, and were about to depart, Messer Geri

1010.01.text:
gave a grand banquet, to which he bade some
of the most honourable of the citizens, and

1016.70.text:
also Cisti, who could by no means be induced
to come. However, Messer Geri bade one of

1026.05.text:
his servants go fetch a flask of Cisti's wine,
and serve half a beaker thereof to each guest

1031.89.text:
at the first course. The servant, somewhat
offended, perhaps, that he had not been suffered

1039.48.text:
to taste any of the wine, took with him a
large flask, which Cisti no sooner saw, than:

1047.19.text:
"Son," quoth he, "Messer Geri does not send
thee to me": and often as the servant affirmed

1055.31.text:
that he did, he could get no other answer:
wherewith he was fain at last to return to

1062.45.text:
Messer Geri. "Go, get thee back," said Messer
Geri, "and tell him that I do send thee to

1071.71.text:
him, and if he answers thee so again, ask
him, to whom then I send thee." So the servant

1080.57.text:
came back, and said: "Cisti, Messer Geri does,
for sure, send me to thee." "Son," answered

1091.14.text:
Cisti, "Messer Geri does, for sure, not send
thee to me." "To whom then," said the servant,

1105.38.text:
"does he send me?" "To Arno," returned Cisti.
Which being reported by the servant to Messer

1115.90.text:
Geri, the eyes of his mind were straightway
opened, and: "Let me see," quoth he to the

1124.59.text:
servant, "what flask it is thou takest there."
And when he had seen it: "Cisti says sooth,"

1136.03.text:
he added; and having sharply chidden him,
he caused him take with him a suitable flask,

1145.07.text:
which when Cisti saw: "Now know I," quoth
he, "that 'tis indeed Messer Geri that sends

1153.84.text:
thee to me," and blithely filled it. And having
replenished the rundlet that same day with

1163.74.text:
wine of the same quality, he had it carried
with due care to Messer Geri's house, and

1172.23.text:
followed after himself; where finding Messer
Geri he said: "I would not have you think,

1178.48.text:
Sir, that I was appalled by the great flask
your servant brought me this morning; 'twas

1184.87.text:
but that I thought you had forgotten that
which by my little beakers I gave you to understand,

1191.62.text:
when you were with me of late; to wit, that
this is no table wine; and so wished this

1198.93.text:
morning to refresh your memory. Now, however,
being minded to keep the wine no longer, I

1207.75.text:
have sent you all I have of it, to be henceforth
entirely at your disposal." Messer Geri set

1215.27.text:
great store by Cisti's gift, and thanked him
accordingly, and ever made much of him and

1230.72.text: End of Day Six, The Second Story

1244.05.text:
Monna Nonna de' Pulci by a ready retort silences
the scarce seemly jesting of the Bishop of

1251.96.text:
Pampinea's story ended, and praise not a little
bestowed on Cisti alike for his apt speech

1259.75.text:
and for his handsome present, the queen was
pleased to call forthwith for a story from

1270.15.text:
Debonair my ladies, the excellency of wit,
and our lack thereof, have been noted with

1275.45.text:
no small truth first by Pampinea and after
her by Filomena. To which topic 'twere bootless

1280.88.text:
to return: wherefore to that which has been
said touching the nature of wit I purpose

1286.19.text:
but to add one word, to remind you that its
bite should be as a sheep's bite and not as

1291.75.text:
a dog's; for if it bite like a dog, 'tis no
longer wit but discourtesy. With which maxim

1298.43.text:
the words of Madonna Oretta, and the apt reply
of Cisti, accorded excellently. True indeed

1305.26.text:
it is that if 'tis by way of retort, and one
that has received a dog's bite gives the biter

1310.83.text:
a like bite in return, it does not seem to
be reprehensible, as otherwise it would have

1316.55.text:
been. Wherefore one must consider how and
when and on whom and likewise where one exercises

1322.52.text:
one's wit. By ill observing which matters
one of our prelates did once upon a time receive

1328.90.text:
no less shrewd a bite than he gave; as I will
shew you in a short story.

1336.21.text:
While Messer Antonio d'Orso, a prelate both
worthy and wise, was Bishop of Florence, there

1342.30.text:
came thither a Catalan gentleman, Messer Dego
della Ratta by name, being King Ruberto's

1348.47.text:
marshal. Now Dego being very goodly of person,
and inordinately fond of women, it so befell

1356.01.text:
that of the ladies of Florence she that he
regarded with especial favour was the very

1361.81.text:
beautiful niece of a brother of the said bishop.
And having learned that her husband, though

1367.72.text:
of good family, was but a caitiff, and avaricious
in the last degree, he struck a bargain with

1373.84.text:
him that he should lie one night with the
lady for five hundred florins of gold: whereupon

1380.51.text:
he had the same number of popolins of silver,
which were then current, gilded, and having

1386.12.text:
lain with the lady, albeit against her will,
gave them to her husband. Which coming to

1392.45.text:
be generally known, the caitiff husband was
left with the loss and the laugh against him;

1397.69.text:
and the bishop, like a wise man, feigned to
know nought of the affair. And so the bishop

1403.57.text:
and the marshal being much together, it befell
that on St. John's day, as they rode side

1409.07.text:
by side down the street whence they start
to run the palio, and took note of the ladies,

1414.25.text:
the bishop espied a young gentle-woman, whom
this present pestilence has reft from us,

1419.62.text:
Monna Nonna de' Pulci by name, a cousin of
Messer Alesso Rinucci, whom you all must know;

1425.63.text:
whom, for that she was lusty and fair, and
of excellent discourse and a good courage,

1431.46.text:
and but just settled with her husband in Porta
San Piero, the bishop presented to the marshal;

1437.38.text:
and then, being close beside her, he laid
his hand on the marshal's shoulder and said

1442.64.text:
to her: "Nonna, what thinkest thou of this
gentleman? That thou mightst make a conquest

1447.55.text:
of him?" Which words the lady resented as
a jibe at her honour, and like to tarnish

1453.75.text:
it in the eyes of those, who were not a few,
in whose hearing they were spoken Wherefore

1459.32.text:
without bestowing a thought upon the vindication
of her honour, but being minded to return

1464.01.text:
blow for blow, she retorted hastily: "Perchance,
Sir, he might not make a conquest of me; but

1471.43.text:
if he did so, I should want good money." The
answer stung both the marshal and the bishop

1478.62.text:
to the quick, the one as contriver of the
scurvy trick played upon the bishop's brother

1483.84.text:
in regard of his niece, the other as thereby
outraged in the person of his brother's niece;

1489.24.text:
insomuch that they dared not look one another
in the face, but took themselves off in shame

1494.82.text:
and silence, and said never a word more to
her that day.

1499.61.text:
In such a case, then, the lady having received
a bite, 'twas allowable in her wittily to

1509.45.text: End of Day Six, The Third Story

1518.03.text:
Chichibio, cook to Currado Gianfigliazzi,
owes his safety to a ready answer, whereby

1526.44.text:
he converts Currado's wrath into laughter,
and evades the evil fate with which Currado

1533.93.text:
Lauretta being now silent, all lauded Nonna
to the skies; after which Neifile received

1540.78.text:
the queen's command to follow suit, and thus
began:

1544.52.text:
Albeit, loving ladies, ready wit not seldom
ministers words apt and excellent and congruous

1551.62.text:
with the circumstances of the speakers, 'tis
also true that Fortune at times comes to the

1557.78.text:
aid of the timid, and unexpectedly sets words
upon the tongue, which in a quiet hour the

1563.83.text:
speaker could never have found for himself:
the which 'tis my purpose to shew you by my

1571.83.text:
Currado Gianfigliazzi, as the eyes and ears
of each of you may bear witness, has ever

1578.33.text:
been a noble citizen of our city, open-handed
and magnificent, and one that lived as a gentleman

1585.17.text:
should with hounds and hawks, in which, to
say nothing at present of more important matters,

1591.01.text:
he found unfailing delight. Now, having one
day hard by Peretola despatched a crane with

1598.90.text:
one of his falcons, finding it young and plump,
he sent it to his excellent cook, a Venetian,

1606.17.text:
Chichibio by name, bidding him roast it for
supper and make a dainty dish of it. Chichibio,

1613.35.text:
who looked, as he was, a very green-head,
had dressed the crane, and set it to the fire

1619.64.text:
and was cooking it carefully, when, the bird
being all but roasted, and the fumes of the

1625.03.text:
cooking very strong, it so chanced that a
girl, Brunetta by name, that lived in the

1630.99.text:
same street, and of whom Chichibio was greatly
enamoured, came into the kitchen, and perceiving

1637.53.text:
the smell and seeing the bird, began coaxing
Chichibio to give her a thigh. By way of answer

1645.10.text:
Chichibio fell a singing: "You get it not
from me, Madam Brunetta, you get it not from

1650.78.text:
me."Whereat Madam Brunetta was offended, and
said to him: "By God, if thou givest it me

1658.43.text:
not, thou shalt never have aught from me to
pleasure thee." In short there was not a little

1665.25.text:
altercation; and in the end Chichibio, fain
not to vex his mistress, cut off one of the

1672.44.text:
crane's thighs, and gave it to her. So the
bird was set before Currado and some strangers

1679.28.text:
that he had at table with him, and Currado,
observing that it had but one thigh, was surprised,

1687.24.text:
and sent for Chichibio, and demanded of him
what was become of the missing thigh. Whereto

1694.78.text:
the mendacious Venetian answered readily:
"The crane, Sir, has but one thigh and one

1700.70.text:
leg." "What the devil?" rejoined Currado in
a rage: "so the crane has but one thigh and

1708.00.text:
one leg? thinkst thou I never saw crane before
this?" But Chichibio continued: "'Tis even

1715.31.text:
so as I say, Sir; and, so please you, I will
shew you that so it is in the living bird."

1721.46.text:
Currado had too much respect for his guests
to pursue the topic; he only said: "Since

1728.60.text:
thou promisest to shew me in the living bird
what I have never seen or heard tell of, I

1734.85.text:
bid thee do so to-morrow, and I shall be satisfied,
but if thou fail, I swear to thee by the body

1743.06.text:
of Christ that I will serve thee so that thou
shalt ruefully remember my name for the rest

1749.82.text:
No more was said of the matter that evening,
but on the morrow, at daybreak, Currado, who

1757.74.text:
had by no means slept off his wrath, got up
still swelling therewith, and ordered his

1764.15.text:
horses, mounted Chichibio on a hackney, and
saying to him: "We shall soon see which of

1770.54.text:
us lied yesternight, thou or I," set off with
him for a place where there was much water,

1777.07.text:
beside which there were always cranes to be
seen about dawn. Chichibio, observing that

1784.93.text:
Currado's ire was unabated, and knowing not
how to bolster up his lie, rode by Currado's

1792.08.text:
side in a state of the utmost trepidation,
and would gladly, had he been able, have taken

1797.83.text:
to flight; but, as hemight not, he glanced,
now ahead, now aback, now aside, and saw everywhere

1807.72.text:
nought but cranes standing on two feet. However,
as they approached the river, the very first

1816.58.text:
thing they saw upon the bank was a round dozen
of cranes standing each and all on one foot,

1823.31.text:
as is their wont, when asleep. Which Chichibio
presently pointed out to Currado, saying:

1830.10.text:
"Now may you see well enough, Sir, that 'tis
true as I said yesternight, that the crane

1835.27.text:
has but one thigh and one leg; mark but how
they stand over there." Whereupon Currado:

1842.20.text:
"Wait," quoth he, "and I will shew thee that
they have each thighs and legs twain." So,

1851.18.text:
having drawn a little nigher to them, he ejaculated,
"Ohio!" Which caused the cranes to bring each

1858.32.text:
the other foot to the ground, and, after hopping
a step or two, to take to flight. Currado

1864.56.text:
then turned to Chichibio, saying: "How now,
rogue? art satisfied that the bird has thighs

1871.55.text:
and legs twain?" Whereto Chichibio, all but
beside himself with fear, made answer: "Ay,

1879.24.text:
Sir; but you cried not, oho! to our crane
of yestereve: had you done so, it would have

1885.85.text:
popped its other thigh and foot forth, as
these have done." Which answer Currado so

1891.59.text:
much relished, that, all his wrath changed
to jollity and laughter: "Chichibio," quoth

1897.61.text:
he, "thou art right, indeed I ought to have
so done."

1903.68.text:
Thus did Chichibio by his ready and jocund
retort arrest impending evil, and make his

1911.16.text:
peace with his master.
Messer Forese da Rabatta and Master Giotto,

1927.82.text:
the painter, journeying together from Mugello,
deride one another's scurvy appearance.

1937.76.text:
Neifile being silent, and the ladies having
made very merry over Chichibio's retort, Pamfilo

1944.40.text: at the queen's command thus spoke:

1946.95.text:
Dearest ladies, if Fortune, as Pampinea has
shewn us, does sometimes hide treasures most

1954.67.text:
rich of native worth in the obscurity of base
occupations, so in like manner 'tis not seldom

1962.29.text:
found that Nature has enshrined prodigies
of wit in the most ignoble of human forms.

1969.94.text:
Whereof a notable example is afforded by two
of our citizens, of whom I purpose for a brief

1975.75.text:
while to discourse. The one, Messer Forese
da Rabatta by name, was short and deformed

1983.86.text:
of person and withal flat-cheeked and flat-nosed,
insomuch that never a Baroncio had a visage

1992.00.text:
so misshapen but his would have shewed as
hideous beside it; yet so conversant was this

1998.36.text:
man with the laws, that by not a few of those
well able to form an opinion he was reputed

2004.92.text:
a veritable storehouse of civil jurisprudence.
The other, whose name was Giotto, was of so

2013.69.text:
excellent a wit that, let Nature, mother of
all, operant ever by continual revolution

2020.68.text:
of the heavens, fashion what she would, he
with his style and pen and pencil would depict

2027.72.text:
its like on such wise that it shewed not as
its like, but rather as the thing itself,

2034.72.text:
insomuch that the visual sense of men did
often err in regard thereof, mistaking for

2039.89.text:
real that which was but painted. Wherefore,
having brought back to light that art which

2047.41.text:
had for many ages lain buried beneath the
blunders of those who painted rather to delight

2052.72.text:
the eyes of the ignorant than to satisfy the
intelligence of the wise, he may deservedly

2058.81.text:
be called one of the lights that compose the
glory of Florence, and the more so, the more

2064.75.text:
lowly was the spirit in which he won that
glory, who, albeit he was, while he yet lived,

2071.78.text:
the master of others, yet did ever refuse
to be called their master. And this title

2078.49.text:
that he rejected adorned him with a lustre
the more splendid in proportion to the avidity

2084.66.text:
with which it was usurped by those who were
less knowing than he, or were his pupils.

2091.95.text:
But for all the exceeding greatness of his
art, yet in no particular had he the advantage

2097.43.text:
of Messer Forese either in form or in feature.
But to come to the story: 'Twas in Mugello

2105.97.text:
that Messer Forese, as likewise Giotto, had
his country-seat, whence returning from a

2112.23.text:
sojourn that he had made there during the
summer vacation of the courts, and being,

2117.17.text:
as it chanced, mounted on a poor jade of a
draught horse, he fell in with the said Giotto,

2123.75.text:
who was also on his way back to Florence after
a like sojourn on his own estate, and was

2129.37.text:
neither better mounted, nor in any other wise
better equipped, than Messer Forese. And so,

2136.69.text:
being both old men, they jogged on together
at a slow pace: and being surprised by a sudden

2143.53.text:
shower, such as we frequently see fall in
summer, they presently sought shelter in the

2148.26.text:
house of a husbandman that was known to each
of them, and was their friend. But after a

2154.73.text:
while, as the rain gave no sign of ceasing,
and they had a mind to be at Florence that

2160.17.text:
same day, they borrowed of the husbandman
two old cloaks of Romagnole cloth, and two

2168.47.text:
hats much the worse for age (there being no
better to be had), and resumed their journey.

2175.61.text:
Whereon they had not proceeded far, when,
taking note that they were soaked through

2181.09.text:
and through, and liberally splashed with the
mud cast up by their nags' hooves (circumstances

2188.10.text:
which are not of a kind to add to one's dignity),
they, after long silence, the sky beginning

2194.75.text:
to brighten a little, began to converse. And
Messer Forese, as he rode and hearkened to

2200.99.text:
Giotto, who was an excellent talker, surveyed
him sideways, and from head to foot, and all

2208.17.text:
over, and seeing him in all points in so sorry
and scurvy a trim, and recking nought of his

2214.67.text:
own appearance, broke into a laugh and said:
"Giotto, would e'er a stranger that met us,

2222.60.text:
and had not seen thee before, believe, thinkst
thou, that thou wert, as thou art, the greatest

2229.59.text:
painter in the world." Whereto Giotto answered
promptly: "Methinks, Sir, he might, if, scanning

2238.32.text:
you, he gave you credit for knowing the A
B C." Which hearing, Messer Forese recognized

2246.35.text:
his error, and perceived that he had gotten
as good as he brought.

2250.98.text: End of Day Six, The Fifth Story

2262.04.text:
Michele Scalza proves to certain young men
that the Baronci are the best gentlemen in

2268.59.text: the world and the Maremma, and wins a supper.

2271.52.text:
The ladies were still laughing over Giotto's
ready retort, when the queen charged Fiammetta

2277.32.text: to follow suit; wherefore thus Fiammetta began:

2280.95.text:
Pamfilo's mention of the Baronci, who to you,
Damsels, are perchance not so well known as

2286.42.text:
to him, has brought to my mind a story in
which 'tis shewn how great is their nobility;

2292.14.text:
and, for that it involves no deviation from
our rule of discourse, I am minded to tell

2299.60.text:
'Tis no long time since there dwelt in our
city a young man, Michele Scalza by name,

2305.17.text:
the pleasantest and merriest fellow in the
world, and the best furnished with quaint

2309.54.text:
stories: for which reason the Florentine youth
set great store on having him with them when

2315.57.text:
they forgathered in company. Now it so befell
that one day, he being with a party of them

2323.35.text:
at Mont' Ughi, they fell a disputing together
on this wise; to wit, who were the best gentlemen

2330.17.text:
and of the longest descent in Florence. One
said, the Uberti, another, the Lamberti, or

2337.82.text:
some other family, according to the predilection
of the speaker. Whereat Scalza began to smile,

2344.88.text:
and said: "Now out upon you, out upon you,
blockheads that ye are: ye know not what ye

2352.11.text:
say. The best gentlemen and of longest descent
in all the world and the Maremma (let alone

2358.27.text:
Florence) are the Baronci by the common consent
of all phisopholers, and all that know them

2364.75.text:
as I do; and lest you should otherwise conceive
me, I say that 'tis of your neighbours the

2369.85.text:
Baronci of Santa Maria Maggiore that I speak."
Whereupon the young men, who had looked for

2377.63.text:
somewhat else from him, said derisively: "Thou
dost but jest with us; as if we did not know

2384.12.text:
the Baronci as well as thou!" Quoth Scalza:
"By the Gospels I jest not, but speak sooth;

2392.23.text:
and if there is any of you will wager a supper
to be given to the winner and six good fellows

2396.96.text:
whom he shall choose, I will gladly do the
like, and—what is more—I will abide by

2402.79.text:
the decision of such one of you as you may
choose." Then said one of them whose name

2408.94.text:
was Neri Mannini: "I am ready to adventure
this supper;" and so they agreed together

2415.47.text:
that Piero di Fiorentino, in whose house they
were, should be judge, and hied them to him

2421.16.text:
followed by all the rest, eager to see Scalza
lose, and triumph in his discomfiture, and

2427.90.text:
told Piero all that had been said. Piero,
who was a young man of sound sense, heard

2434.24.text:
what Neri had to say; and then turning to
Scalza: "And how," quoth he, "mayst thou make

2441.50.text:
good what thou averrest?" "I will demonstrate
it," returned Scalza, "by reasoning so cogent

2448.71.text:
that not only you, but he that denies it shall
acknowledge that I say sooth. You know, and

2456.10.text:
so they were saying but now, that the longer
men's descent, the better is their gentility,

2462.16.text:
and I say that the Baronci are of longer descent,
and thus better gentlemen than any other men.

2468.97.text:
If, then, I prove to you that they are of
longer descent than any other men, without

2474.32.text:
a doubt the victory in this dispute will rest
with me. Now you must know that when God made

2481.79.text:
the Baronci, He was but a novice in His art,
of which, when He made the rest of mankind,

2488.36.text:
He was already master. And to assure yourself
that herein I say sooth, you have but to consider

2495.27.text:
the Baronci, how they differ from the rest
of mankind, who all have faces well composed

2501.53.text:
and duly proportioned, whereas of the Baronci
you will see one with a face very long and

2509.35.text:
narrow, another with a face inordinately broad,
one with a very long nose, another with a

2514.39.text:
short one, one with a protruding and upturned
chin, and great jaws like an ass's; and again

2520.87.text:
there will be one that has one eye larger
than its fellow, or set on a lower plane;

2526.46.text:
so that their faces resemble those that children
make when they begin to learn to draw. Whereby,

2532.24.text:
as I said, 'tis plainly manifest that, when
God made them, He was but novice in His art;

2539.13.text:
and so they are of longer descent than the
rest of mankind, and by consequence better

2546.20.text:
gentlemen." By which entertaining argument
Piero, the judge, and Neri who had wagered

2553.74.text:
the supper, and all the rest, calling to mind
the Baronci's ugliness, were so tickled, that

2559.74.text:
they fell a laughing, and averred that Scalza
was in the right, and that he had won the

2564.99.text:
wager, and that without a doubt the Baronci
were the best gentlemen, and of the longest

2570.02.text:
descent, not merely in Florence, but in the
world and the Maremma to boot. Wherefore 'twas

2576.97.text:
not without reason that Pamfilo, being minded
to declare Messer Forese's ill-favouredness,

2583.60.text:
said that he would have been hideous beside
a Baroncio.

2588.93.text: End of Day Six, The Sixth Story

2598.91.text:
Madonna Filippa, being found by her husband
with her lover, is cited before the court,

2604.61.text:
and by a ready and jocund answer acquits herself,
and brings about an alteration of the statute.

2611.35.text:
Fiammetta had been silent some time, but Scalza's
novel argument to prove the pre-eminent nobility

2618.04.text:
of the Baronci kept all still laughing, when
the queen called for a story from Filostrato,

2626.61.text:
Noble ladies, an excellent thing is apt speech
on all occasions, but to be proficient therein

2633.00.text:
I deem then most excellent when the occasion
does most imperatively demand it. As was the

2638.65.text:
case with a gentlewoman, of whom I purpose
to speak to you, who not only ministered gaiety

2644.34.text:
and merriment to her hearers, but extricated
herself, as you shall hear, from the toils

2652.17.text:
There was aforetime in the city of Prato a
statute no less censurable than harsh, which,

2658.92.text:
making no distinction between the wife whom
her husband took in adultery with her lover,

2664.41.text:
and the woman found pleasuring a stranger
for money, condemned both alike to be burned.

2669.68.text:
While this statute was in force, it befell
that a gentle-woman, fair and beyond measure

2675.28.text:
enamoured, Madonna Filippa by name, was by
her husband, Rinaldo de' Pugliesi, found in

2682.90.text:
her own chamber one night in the arms of Lazzarino
de' Guazzagliotri, a handsome young noble

2689.30.text:
of the same city, whom she loved even as herself.
Whereat Rinaldo, very wroth, scarce refrained

2697.11.text:
from falling upon them and killing them on
the spot; and indeed, but that he doubted

2702.09.text:
how he should afterwards fare himself, he
had given way to the vehemence of his anger,

2707.30.text:
and so done. Nor, though he so far mastered
himself, could he forbear recourse to the

2712.95.text:
statute, thereby to compass that which he
might not otherwise lawfully compass, to wit,

2718.48.text:
the death of his lady. Wherefore, having all
the evidence needful to prove her guilt, he

2724.14.text:
took no further counsel; but, as soon as 'twas
day, he charged the lady and had her summoned.

2731.50.text:
Like most ladies that are veritably enamoured,
the lady was of a high courage; and, though

2737.12.text:
not a few of her friends and kinsfolk sought
to dissuade her, she resolved to appear to

2741.62.text:
the summons, having liefer die bravely confessing
the truth than basely flee and for defiance

2748.53.text:
of the law live in exile, and shew herself
unworthy of such a lover as had had her in

2753.69.text:
his arms that night. And so, attended by many
ladies and gentlemen, who all exhorted her

2759.69.text:
to deny the charge, she came before the Podestà,
and with a composed air and unfaltering voice

2766.58.text:
asked whereof he would interrogate her. The
Podestà, surveying her, and taking note of

2771.84.text:
her extraordinary beauty, and exquisite manners,
and the high courage that her words evinced,

2777.52.text:
was touched with compassion for her, fearing
she might make some admission, by reason whereof,

2783.19.text:
to save his honour, he must needs do her to
death. But still, as he could not refrain

2789.07.text:
from examining her of that which was laid
to her charge, he said: "Madam, here, as you

2795.57.text:
see, is your husband, Rinaldo, who prefers
a charge against you, alleging that he has

2800.69.text:
taken you in adultery, and so he demands that,
pursuant to a statute which is in force here,

2806.89.text:
I punish you with death: but this I may not
do, except you confess; wherefore be very

2813.33.text:
careful what you answer, and tell me if what
your husband alleges against you be true."

2819.55.text:
The lady, no wise dismayed, and in a tone
not a little jocund, thus made answer: "True

2825.93.text:
it is, Sir, that Rinaldo is my husband, and
that last night he found me in the arms of

2831.91.text:
Lazzarino, in whose arms for the whole-hearted
love that I bear him I have ofttimes lain;

2838.85.text:
nor shall I ever deny it; but, as well I wot
you know, the laws ought to be common and

2844.48.text:
enacted with the common consent of all that
they affect; which conditions are wanting

2848.85.text:
to this law, inasmuch as it binds only us
poor women, in whom to be liberal is much

2854.74.text:
less reprehensible than it were in men; and
furthermore the consent of no woman was—I

2860.42.text:
say not had, but—so much as asked before
'twas made; for which reasons it justly deserves

2867.45.text:
to be called a bad law. However, if in scathe
of my body and your own soul, you are minded

2874.05.text:
to put it in force, 'tis your affair; but,
I pray you, go not on to try this matter in

2880.76.text:
any wise, until you have granted me this trifling
grace, to wit, to ask my husband if I ever

2887.18.text:
gainsaid him, but did not rather accord him,
when and so often as he craved it, complete

2892.74.text:
enjoyment of myself." Whereto Rinaldo, without
awaiting the Podestà's question, forthwith

2898.84.text:
answered, that assuredly the lady had ever
granted him all that he had asked of her for

2903.32.text:
his gratification. "Then," promptly continued
the lady, "if he has ever had of me as much

2910.37.text:
as sufficed for his solace, what was I or
am I to do with the surplus? Am I to cast

2916.83.text:
it to the dogs? Is it not much better to bestow
it on a gentleman that loves me more dearly

2921.63.text:
than himself, than to suffer it to come to
nought or worse?" Which jocund question being

2927.78.text:
heard by well-nigh all the folk of Prato,
who had flocked thither all agog to see a

2932.80.text:
dame so fair and of such quality on her trial
for such an offence, they laughed loud and

2938.81.text:
long, and then all with one accord, and as
with one voice, exclaimed that the lady was

2944.86.text:
in the right and said well; nor left they
the court until in concert with the Podestà

2950.89.text:
they had so altered the harsh statute as that
thenceforth only such women as should wrong

2956.40.text:
their husbands for money should be within
its purview.

2961.89.text:
Wherefore Rinaldo left the court, discomfited
of his foolish enterprise; and the lady blithe

2967.77.text:
and free, as if rendered back to life from
the burning, went home triumphant.

2974.29.text: End of Day Six, The Seventh Story

2983.67.text:
Fresco admonishes his niece not to look at
herself in the glass, if'tis, as she says,

2988.23.text: grievous to her to see nasty folk.

2990.61.text:
'Twas not at first without some flutterings
of shame, evinced by the modest blush mantling

2996.74.text:
on their cheeks, that the ladies heard Filostrato's
story; but afterwards, exchanging glances,

3003.95.text:
they could scarce forbear to laugh, and hearkened
tittering. However, when he had done, the

3010.78.text:
queen turning to Emilia bade her follow suit.
Whereupon Emilia, fetching a deep breath as

3017.06.text: if she were roused from sleep, thus began:

3020.53.text:
Loving ladies, brooding thought has kept my
spirit for so long time remote from here that

3026.07.text:
perchance I may make a shift to satisfy our
queen with a much shorter story than would

3030.54.text:
have been forthcoming but for my absence of
mind, wherein I purpose to tell you how a

3035.38.text:
young woman's folly was corrected by her uncle
with a pleasant jest, had she but had the

3042.15.text:
My story, then, is of one, Fresco da Celatico
by name, that had a niece, Ciesca, as she

3048.19.text:
was playfully called, who, being fair of face
and person, albeit she had none of those angelical

3053.65.text:
charms that we ofttimes see, had so superlative
a conceit of herself, that she had contracted

3059.22.text:
a habit of disparaging both men and women
and all that she saw, entirely regardless

3063.82.text:
of her own defects, though for odiousness,
tiresomeness, and petulance she had not her

3069.55.text:
match among women, insomuch that there was
nought that could be done to her mind: besides

3074.99.text:
which, such was her pride that had she been
of the blood royal of France, 'twould have

3079.61.text:
been inordinate. And when she walked abroad,
so fastidious was her humour, she was ever

3084.36.text:
averting her head, as if there was never a
soul she saw or met but reeked with a foul

3089.97.text:
smell. Now one day—not to speak of other
odious and tiresome ways that she had—it

3095.42.text:
so befell that being come home, where Fresco
was, she sat herself down beside him with

3100.43.text:
a most languishing air, and did nought but
fume and chafe. Whereupon: "Ciesca," quoth

3106.47.text:
he, "what means this, that, though 'tis a
feast-day, yet thou art come back so soon?"

3113.12.text:
She, all but dissolved with her vapourish
humours, made answer: "Why, the truth is,

3119.56.text:
that I am come back early because never, I
believe, were there such odious and tiresome

3124.36.text:
men and women in this city as there are to-day.
I cannot pass a soul in the street that I

3129.92.text:
loathe not like ill-luck; and I believe there
is not a woman in the world that is so distressed

3134.75.text:
by the sight of odious people as I am; and
so I am come home thus soon to avoid the sight

3140.11.text:
of them." Whereupon Fresco, to whom his niece's
bad manners were distasteful in the extreme:

3146.30.text:
"Daughter," quoth he, "if thou loathe odious
folk as much as thou sayest, thou wert best,

3152.32.text:
so thou wouldst live happy, never to look
at thyself in the glass." But she, empty as

3158.99.text:
a reed, albeit in her own conceit a match
for Solomon in wisdom, was as far as any sheep

3164.05.text:
from apprehending the true sense of her uncle's
jest; but answered that on the contrary she

3168.88.text:
was minded to look at herself in the glass
like otherwomen. And so she remained, and

3173.93.text: yet remains, hidebound in her folly.

3178.08.text: End of Day Six, The Eighth Story

3187.67.text:
Guido Cavalcanti by a quip meetly rebukes
certain Florentine gentlemen who had taken

3199.16.text:
The queen, perceiving that Emilia had finished
her story, and that none but she, and he who

3206.23.text:
had the privilege of speaking last, now remained
to tell, began on this wise:

3212.56.text:
Albeit, debonair my ladies, you have forestalled
me to-day of more than two of the stories,

3218.88.text:
of which I had thought to tell one, yet one
is still left me to recount, which carries

3225.48.text:
at the close of it a quip of such a sort,
that perhaps we have as yet heard nought so

3234.05.text:
You are to know, then, that in former times
there obtained in our city customs excellent

3239.75.text:
and commendable not a few, whereof today not
one is left to us, thanks to the greed which,

3246.73.text:
growing with the wealth of our folk, has banished
them all from among us. One of which customs

3252.45.text:
was that in divers quarters of Florence the
gentlemen that there resided would assemble

3258.01.text:
together in companies of a limited number,
taking care to include therein only such as

3264.88.text:
might conveniently bear the expenses, and
to-day one, another to-morrow, each in his

3271.55.text:
turn for a day, would entertain the rest of
the company; and so they would not seldom

3276.96.text:
do honour to gentlemen from distant parts
when they visited the city, and also to their

3283.72.text:
fellow-citizens; and in like manner they would
meet together at least once a year all in

3288.94.text:
the same trim, and on the most notable days
would ride together through the city, and

3294.73.text:
now and again they would tilt together, more
especially on the greater feasts, or when

3300.42.text:
the city was rejoiced by tidings of victory
or some other glad event. Among which companies

3307.08.text:
was one of which Messer Betto Brunelleschi
was the leading spirit, into which Messer

3312.52.text:
Betto and his comrades had striven hard to
bring Guido, son of Cavalcante de' Cavalcanti,

3320.66.text:
and not without reason, inasmuch as, besides
being one of the best logicians in the world,

3327.34.text:
and an excellent natural philosopher (qualities
of which the company made no great account),

3333.04.text:
he was without a peer for gallantry and courtesy
and excellence of discourse and aptitude for

3339.31.text:
all matters which he might set his mind to,
and that belonged to a gentleman; and therewithal

3345.05.text:
he was very rich, and, when he deemed any
worthy of honour, knew how to bestow it to

3350.73.text:
the uttermost. But, as Messer Betto had never
been able to gain him over, he and his comrades

3357.80.text:
supposed that 'twas because Guido, being addicted
to speculation, was thereby estranged from

3363.45.text:
men. And, for that he was somewhat inclined
to the opinion of the Epicureans, the vulgar

3369.67.text:
averred that these speculations of his had
no other scope than to prove that God did

3375.14.text:
not exist. Now one day it so befell that,
Guido being come, as was not seldom his wont,

3384.42.text:
from Or San Michele by the Corso degli Adimari
as far as San Giovanni, around which were

3392.39.text:
then the great tombs of marble that are to-day
in Santa Reparata, besides other tombs not

3399.16.text:
a few, and Guido being between the columns
of porphyry, that are there, and the tombs

3405.82.text:
and the door of San Giovanni, which was locked,
Messer Betto and his company came riding on

3412.43.text:
to the piazza of Santa Reparata, and seeing
him among the tombs, said: "Go we and flout

3419.35.text:
him." So they set spurs to their horses, and
making a mock onset, were upon him almost

3426.69.text:
before he saw them. Whereupon: "Guido," they
began, "thou wilt be none of our company;

3433.41.text:
but, lo now, when thou hast proved that God
does not exist, what wilt thou have achieved?"

3441.22.text:
Guido, seeing that he was surrounded, presently
answered: "Gentlemen, you may say to me what

3447.70.text:
you please in your own house." Thereupon he
laid his hand on one of the great tombs, and

3454.04.text:
being very nimble, vaulted over it, and so
evaded them, and went his way, while they

3460.11.text:
remained gazing in one another's faces, and
some said that he had taken leave of his wits,

3466.71.text:
and that his answer was but nought, seeing
that the ground on which they stood was common

3473.10.text:
to them with the rest of the citizens, and
among them Guido himself. But Messer Betto,

3479.75.text:
turning to them: "Nay but," quoth he, "'tis
ye that have taken leave of your wits, if

3486.73.text:
ye have not understood him; for meetly and
in few words he has given us never so shrewd

3493.88.text:
a reprimand; seeing that, if you consider
it well, these tombs are the houses of the

3501.31.text:
dead, that are laid and tarry therein; which
he calls our house, to shew us that we, and

3508.31.text:
all other simple, unlettered men, are, in
comparison of him and the rest of the learned,

3515.47.text:
in sorrier case than dead men, and so being
here, we are in our own house." Then none

3523.68.text:
was there but understood Guido's meaning and
was abashed, insomuch that they flouted him

3529.80.text:
no more, and thenceforth reputed Messer Betto
a gentleman of a subtle and discerning wit.

3537.67.text: End of Day Six, The Ninth Story

3549.92.text:
Fra Cipolla promises to shew certain country-folk
a feather of the Angel Gabriel, in lieu of

3555.99.text:
which he finds coals, which he avers to be
of those with which St. Lawrence was roasted.

3562.96.text:
All the company save Dioneo being delivered
of their several stories, he wist that 'twas

3569.07.text:
his turn to speak. Wherefore, without awaiting
any very express command, he enjoined silence

3576.15.text:
on those that were commending Guido's pithy
quip, and thus began:

3582.25.text:
Sweet my ladies, albeit 'tis my privilege
to speak of what likes me most, I purpose

3588.24.text:
not to-day to deviate from that theme whereon
you have all discoursed most appositely; but,

3594.15.text:
following in your footsteps, I am minded to
shew you with what adroitness and readiness

3598.84.text:
of resource one of the Friars of St. Antony
avoided a pickle that two young men had in

3603.76.text:
readiness for him. Nor, if, in order to do
the story full justice, I be somewhat prolix

3609.64.text:
of speech, should it be burdensome to you,
if you will but glance at the sun, which is

3615.10.text:
Certaldo, as perchance you may have heard,
is a town of Val d'Elsa within our country-side,

3622.01.text:
which, small though it is, had in it aforetime
people of rank and wealth. Thither, for that

3628.85.text:
there he found good pasture, 'twas long the
wont of one of the Friars of St. Antony to

3632.96.text:
resort once every year, to collect the alms
that fools gave them. Fra Cipolla—so hight

3639.51.text:
the friar—met with a hearty welcome, no
less, perchance, by reason of his name than

3644.68.text:
for other cause, the onions produced in that
district being famous throughout Tuscany.

3651.00.text:
He was little of person, red-haired, jolly-visaged,
and the very best of good fellows; and therewithal,

3657.24.text:
though learning he had none, he was so excellent
and ready a speaker that whoso knew him not

3663.47.text:
would not only have esteemed him a great rhetorician,
but would have pronounced him Tully himself

3668.15.text:
or, perchance, Quintilian; and in all the
country-side there was scarce a soul to whom

3673.48.text:
he was not either gossip or friend or lover.
Being thus wont from time to time to visit

3678.84.text:
Certaldo, the friar came there once upon a
time in the month of August, and on a Sunday

3684.91.text:
morning, all the good folk of the neighbouring
farms being come to mass in the parish church,

3689.90.text:
he took occasion to come forward and say:
"Ladies and gentlemen, you wot 'tis your custom

3695.34.text:
to send year by year to the poor of Baron
Master St. Antony somewhat of your wheat and

3700.67.text:
oats, more or less, according to the ability
and the devoutness of each, that blessed St.

3706.01.text:
Antony may save your oxen and asses and pigs
and sheep from harm; and you are also accustomed,

3712.57.text:
and especially those whose names are on the
books of our confraternity, to pay your trifling

3717.34.text:
annual dues. To collect which offerings, I
am hither sent by my superior, to wit, Master

3723.17.text:
Abbot; wherefore, with the blessing of God,
after none, when you hear the bells ring,

3729.09.text:
you will come out of the church to the place
where in the usual way I shall deliver you

3733.54.text:
my sermon, and you will kiss the cross; and
therewithal, knowing, as I do, that you are

3739.21.text:
one and all most devoted to Baron Master St.
Antony, I will by way of especial grace shew

3745.54.text:
you a most holy and goodly relic, which I
brought myself from the Holy Land overseas,

3751.63.text:
which is none other than one of the feathers
of the Angel Gabriel, which he left behind

3757.12.text:
him in the room of the Virgin Mary, when he
came to make her the annunciation in Nazareth."

3762.72.text:
And having said thus much, he ceased, and
went on with the mass. Now among the many

3768.27.text:
that were in the church, while Fra Cipolla
made this speech, were two very wily young

3773.55.text:
wags, the one Giovanni del Bragoniera by name,
the other Biagio Pizzini; who, albeit they

3780.91.text:
were on the best of terms with Fra Cipolla
and much in his company, had a sly laugh together

3786.65.text:
over the relic, and resolved to make game
of him and his feather. So, having learned

3792.32.text:
that Fra Cipolla was to breakfast that morning
in the town with one of his friends, as soon

3797.26.text:
as they knew that he was at table, down they
hied them into the street, and to the inn

3802.29.text:
where the friar lodged, having complotted
that Biagio should keep the friar's servant

3807.18.text:
in play, while Giovanni made search among
the friar's goods and chattels for this feather,

3813.10.text:
whatever it might be, to carry it off, that
they might see how the friar would afterwards

3818.09.text:
explain the matter to the people. Now Fra
Cipolla had for servant one Guccio, whom some

3824.78.text:
called by way of addition Balena, others Imbratta,
others again Porco, and who was such a rascallion

3831.52.text:
that sure it is that Lippo Topo himself never
painted his like. Concerning whom Fra Cipolla

3838.09.text:
would ofttimes make merry with his familiars,
saying: "My servant has nine qualities, any

3844.31.text:
one of which in Solomon, Aristotle, or Seneca,
would have been enough to spoil all their

3849.11.text:
virtue, wisdom and holiness. Consider, then,
what sort of a man he must be that has these

3854.11.text:
nine qualities, and yet never a spark of either
virtue or wisdom or holiness." And being asked

3860.51.text:
upon divers occasions what these nine qualities
might be, he strung them together in rhyme,

3865.80.text:
and answered: "I will tell you. Lazy and uncleanly
and a liar he is, Negligent, disobedient and

3872.37.text:
foulmouthed, iwis, And reckless and witless
and mannerless: and therewithal he has some

3878.25.text:
other petty vices, which 'twere best to pass
over. And the most amusing thing about him

3883.43.text:
is, that, wherever he goes, he is for taking
a wife and renting a house, and on the strength

3888.42.text:
of a big, black, greasy beard he deems himself
so very handsome a fellow and seductive, that

3894.72.text:
he takes all the women that see him to be
in love with him, and, if he were left alone,

3899.05.text:
he would slip his girdle and run after them
all. True it is that he is of great use to

3903.84.text:
me, for that, be any minded to speak with
me never so secretly, he must still have his

3908.79.text:
share of the audience; and, if perchance aught
is demanded of me, such is his fear lest I

3914.16.text:
should be at a loss what answer to make, that
he presently replies, ay or no, as he deems

3921.24.text:
Now, when he left this knave at the inn, Fra
Cipolla had strictly enjoined him on no account

3927.40.text:
to suffer any one to touch aught of his, and
least of all his wallet, because it contained

3932.31.text:
the holy things. But Guccio Imbratta, who
was fonder of the kitchen than any nightingale

3938.01.text:
of the green boughs, and most particularly
if he espied there a maid, and in the host's

3943.17.text:
kitchen had caught sight of a coarse fat woman,
short and misshapen, with a pair of breasts

3949.73.text:
that shewed as two buckets of muck and a face
that might have belonged to one of the Baronci,

3955.23.text:
all reeking with sweat and grease and smoke,
left Fra Cipolla's room and all his things

3960.91.text:
to take care of themselves, and like a vulture
swooping down upon the carrion, was in the

3966.41.text:
kitchen in a trice. Where, though 'twas August,
he sat him down by the fire, and fell a gossiping

3972.29.text:
with Nuta—such was the maid's name—and
told her that he was a gentleman by procuration,

3978.48.text:
and had more florins than could be reckoned,
besides those that he had to give away, which

3983.01.text:
were rather more than less, and that he could
do and say such things as never were or might

3988.36.text:
be seen or heard forever, good Lord! and a
day. And all heedless of his cowl, which had

3994.30.text:
as much grease upon it as would have furnished
forth the caldron of Altopascio, and of his

3999.02.text:
rent and patched doublet, inlaid with filth
about the neck and under the armpits, and

4004.07.text:
so stained that it shewed hues more various
than ever did silk from Tartary or the Indies,

4009.08.text:
and of his shoes that were all to pieces,
and of his hose that were all in tatters,

4014.87.text:
he told her in a tone that would have become
the Sieur de Châtillon, that he was minded

4019.41.text:
to rehabit her and put her in trim, and raise
her from her abject condition, and place her

4024.91.text:
where, though she would not have much to call
her own, at any rate she would have hope of

4029.24.text:
better things, with much more to the like
effect; which professions, though made with

4034.88.text:
every appearance of good will, proved, like
most of his schemes, insubstantial as air,

4042.46.text:
Finding Guccio Porco thus occupied with Nuta,
the two young men gleefully accounted their

4047.64.text:
work half done, and, none gainsaying them,
entered Fra Cipolla's room, which was open,

4052.94.text:
and lit at once upon the wallet, in which
was the feather. The wallet opened, they found,

4058.99.text:
wrapt up in many folds of taffeta, a little
casket, on opening which they discovered one

4064.51.text:
of the tail-feathers of a parrot, which they
deemed must be that which the friar had promised

4069.26.text:
to shew the good folk of Certaldo. And in
sooth he might well have so imposed upon them,

4074.44.text:
for in those days the luxuries of Egypt had
scarce been introduced into Tuscany, though

4079.52.text:
they have since been brought over in prodigious
abundance, to the grave hurt of all Italy.

4084.80.text:
And though some conversance with them there
was, yet in those parts folk knew next to

4089.55.text:
nothing of them; but, adhering to the honest,
simple ways of their forefathers, had not

4095.28.text:
seen, nay for the most part had not so much
as heard tell of, a parrot.

4100.16.text:
So the young men, having found the feather,
took it out with great glee; and looking around

4105.15.text:
for something to replace it, they espied in
a corner of the room some pieces of coal,

4110.58.text:
wherewith they filled the casket; which they
then closed, and having set the room in order

4115.31.text:
exactly as they had found it, they quitted
it unperceived, and hied them merrily off

4120.15.text:
with the feather, and posted themselves where
they might hear what Fra Cipolla would say

4124.08.text:
when he found the coals in its stead. Mass
said, the simple folk that were in the church

4130.08.text:
went home with the tidings that the feather
of the Angel Gabriel was to be seen after

4134.73.text:
none; and this goodman telling his neighbour,
and that goodwife her gossip, by the time

4140.18.text:
every one had breakfasted, the town could
scarce hold the multitude of men and women

4144.89.text:
that flocked thither all agog to see this
feather.

4148.41.text:
Fra Cipolla, having made a hearty breakfast
and had a little nap, got up shortly after

4153.56.text:
none, and marking the great concourse of country-folk
that were come to see the feather, sent word

4159.06.text:
to Guccio Imbratta to go up there with the
bells, and bring with him the wallet. Guccio,

4163.64.text:
though 'twas with difficulty that he tore
himself away from the kitchen and Nuta, hied

4169.14.text:
him up with the things required; and though,
when he got up, he was winded, for he was

4174.28.text:
corpulent with drinking nought but water,
he did Fra Cipolla's bidding by going to the

4178.77.text:
church door and ringing the bells amain. When
all the people were gathered about the door,

4184.29.text:
Fra Cipolla, all unwitting that aught of his
was missing, began his sermon, and after much

4189.33.text:
said in glorification of himself, caused the
confiteor to be recited with great solemnity,

4195.70.text:
and two torches to be lit by way of preliminary
to the shewing of the feather of the Angel

4199.89.text:
Gabriel: he then bared his head, carefully
unfolded the taffeta, and took out the casket,

4206.66.text:
which, after a few prefatory words in praise
and laudation of the Angel Gabriel and his

4211.85.text:
relic, he opened. When he saw that it contained
nought but coals, he did not suspect Guccio

4219.29.text:
Balena of playing the trick, for he knew that
he was not clever enough, nor did he curse

4223.66.text:
him, that his carelessness had allowed another
to play it, but he inly imprecated himself,

4229.00.text:
that he had committed his things to the keeping
of one whom he knew to be "negligent and disobedient,

4234.60.text:
reckless and witless." Nevertheless, he changed
not colour, but with face and hands upturned

4240.70.text:
to heaven, he said in a voice that all might
hear: "O God, blessed be Thy might for ever

4246.81.text:
and ever." Then, closing the casket, and turning
to the people: "Ladies and gentlemen," he

4253.28.text:
said, "you are to know, that when I was yet
a very young man, I was sent by my superior

4260.33.text:
into those parts where the sun rises, and
I was expressly bidden to search until I should

4265.67.text:
find the Privileges of Porcellana, which,
though they cost nothing to seal, are of much

4271.43.text:
more use to others than to us. On which errand
I set forth, taking my departure from Venice,

4277.91.text:
and traversing the Borgo de' Greci, and thence
on horseback the realm of Algarve, and so

4284.83.text:
by Baldacca I came to Parione, whence, somewhat
athirst, I after a while got on to Sardinia.

4292.50.text:
But wherefore go I about to enumerate all
the lands in which I pursued my quest? Having

4297.87.text:
passed the straits of San Giorgio, I arrived
at Truffia and Buffia, countries thickly populated

4304.31.text:
and with great nations, whence I pursued my
journey to Menzogna, where I met with many

4309.81.text:
of our own brethren, and of other religious
not a few, intent one and all on eschewing

4315.41.text:
hardship for the love of God, making little
account of others' toil, so they might ensue

4320.93.text:
their own advantage, and paying in nought
but unminted coin throughout the length and

4326.00.text:
breadth of the country; and so I came to the
land of Abruzzi, where the men and women go

4332.12.text:
in pattens on the mountains, and clothe the
hogs with their own entrails; and a little

4338.15.text:
further on I found folk that carried bread
in staves and wine in sacks. And leaving them,

4344.67.text:
I arrived at the mountains of the Bachi, where
all the waters run downwards. In short I penetrated

4351.56.text:
so far that I came at last to India Pastinaca,
where I swear to you by the habit that I wear,

4359.28.text:
that I saw pruning-hooks fly: a thing that
none would believe that had not seen it. Whereof

4365.48.text:
be my witness that I lie not Maso del Saggio,
that great merchant, whom I found there cracking

4371.82.text:
nuts, and selling the shells by retail! However,
not being able to find that whereof I was

4378.95.text:
in quest, because from thence one must travel
by water, I turned back, and so came at length

4385.12.text:
to the Holy Land, where in summer cold bread
costs four deniers, and hot bread is to be

4391.09.text:
had for nothing. And there I found the venerable
father Nonmiblasmetesevoipiace, the most worshipful

4399.44.text:
Patriarch of Jerusalem; who out of respect
for the habit that I have ever worn, to wit,

4404.86.text:
that of Baron Master St. Antony, was pleased
to let me see all the holy relics that he

4410.03.text:
had by him, which were so many, that, were
I to enumerate them all, I should not come

4414.25.text:
to the end of them in some miles. However,
not to disappoint you, I will tell you a few

4419.44.text:
of them. In the first place, then, he shewed
me the finger of the Holy Spirit, as whole

4426.06.text:
and entire as it ever was, and the tuft of
the Seraph that appeared to St. Francis, and

4432.09.text:
one of the nails of the Cherubim, and one
of the ribs of the Verbum Caro hie thee to

4437.01.text:
the casement, and some of the vestments of
the Holy Catholic Faith, and some of the rays

4442.12.text:
of the star that appeared to the Magi in the
East, and a phial of the sweat of St. Michael

4448.25.text:
a battling with the Devil and the jaws of
death of St. Lazarus, and other relics. And

4454.53.text:
for that I gave him a liberal supply of the
acclivities of Monte Morello in the vulgar

4459.36.text:
and some chapters of Caprezio, of which he
had long been in quest, he was pleased to

4464.95.text:
let me participate in his holy relics, and
gave me one of the teeth of the Holy Cross,

4471.23.text:
and in a small phial a bit of the sound of
the bells of Solomon's temple, and this feather

4478.43.text:
of the Angel Gabriel, whereof I have told
you, and one of the pattens of San Gherardo

4484.64.text:
da Villa Magna, which, not long ago, I gave
at Florence to Gherardo di Bonsi, who holds

4489.91.text:
him in prodigious veneration. He also gave
me some of the coals with which the most blessed

4496.46.text:
martyr, St. Lawrence, was roasted. All which
things I devoutly brought thence, and have

4502.02.text:
them all safe. True it is that my superior
has not hitherto permitted me to shew them,

4508.47.text:
until he should be certified that they are
genuine. However, now that this is avouched

4514.27.text:
by certain miracles wrought by them, of which
we have tidings by letter from the Patriarch,

4519.89.text:
he has given me leave to shew them. But, fearing
to trust them to another, I always carry them

4525.75.text:
with me; and to tell you the truth I carry
the feather of the Angel Gabriel, lest it

4530.98.text:
should get spoiled, in a casket, and the coals,
with which St. Lawrence was roasted, in another

4537.10.text:
casket; which caskets are so like the one
to the other, that not seldom I mistake one

4542.16.text:
for the other, which has befallen me on this
occasion; for, whereas I thought to have brought

4548.42.text:
with me the casket wherein is the feather,
I have brought instead that which contains

4553.53.text:
the coals. Nor deem l this a mischance; nay,
methinks, 'tis by interposition of God, and

4561.19.text:
that He Himself put the casket of coals in
my hand, for I mind me that the feast of St.

4567.53.text:
Lawrence falls but two days hence. Wherefore
God, being minded that by shewing you the

4573.47.text:
coals, with which he was roasted, I should
rekindle in your souls the devotion that you

4578.38.text:
ought to feel towards him, guided my hand,
not to the feather which I meant to take,

4584.14.text:
but to the blessed coals that were extinguished
by the humours that exuded from that most

4589.02.text:
holy body. And so, blessed children, bare
your heads and devoutly draw nigh to see them.

4597.25.text:
But first of all I would have you know, that
whoso has the sign of the cross made upon

4603.62.text:
him with these coals, may live secure for
the whole of the ensuing year, that fire shall

4610.06.text: not touch him, that he feel it not."

4614.41.text:
Having so said, the friar, chanting a hymn
in praise of St. Lawrence, opened the casket,

4619.60.text:
and shewed the coals. Whereon the foolish
crowd gazed a while in awe and reverent wonder,

4625.64.text:
and then came pressing forward in a mighty
throng about Fra Cipolla with offerings beyond

4630.64.text:
their wont, each and all praying him to touch
them with the coals. Wherefore Fra Cipolla

4637.16.text:
took the coals in his hand, and set about
making on their white blouses, and on their

4642.40.text:
doublets, and on the veils of the women crosses
as big as might be, averring the while that

4648.52.text:
whatever the coals might thus lose would be
made good to them again in the casket, as

4653.85.text:
he had often proved. On this wise, to his
exceeding great profit, he marked all the

4659.77.text:
folk of Certaldo with the cross, and, thanks
to his ready wit and resource, had his laugh

4665.67.text:
at those, who by robbing him of the feather
thought to make a laughing-stock of him. They,

4671.61.text:
indeed, being among his hearers, and marking
his novel expedient, and how voluble he was,

4677.23.text:
and what a long story he made of it, laughed
till they thought their jaws would break;

4682.62.text:
and, when the congregation was dispersed,
they went up to him, and never so merrily

4688.25.text:
told him what they had done, and returned
him his feather; which next year proved no

4694.38.text:
less lucrative to him than that day the coals
had been.

4700.66.text: End of Day Six, The Tenth Story

4709.88.text:
Immense was the delight and diversion which
this story afforded to all the company alike,

4716.26.text:
and great and general was the laughter over
Fra Cipolla, and more especially at his pilgrimage,

4722.46.text:
and the relics, as well those that he had
but seen as those that he had brought back

4728.35.text:
with him. Which being ended, the queen, taking
note that therewith the close of her sovereignty

4736.11.text:
was come, stood up, took off the crown, and
set it on Dioneo's head, saying with a laugh:

4743.34.text:
"'Tis time, Dioneo, that thou prove the weight
of the burden of having ladies to govern and

4749.26.text:
guide. Be thou king then; and let thy rule
be such that, when 'tis ended, we may have

4755.54.text:
cause to commend it." Dioneo took the crown,
and laughingly answered: "Kings worthier far

4763.46.text:
than I you may well have seen many a time
ere now—I speak of the kings in chess; but

4770.87.text:
let me have of you that obedience which is
due to a true king, and of a surety I will

4776.81.text:
give you to taste of that solace, without
which perfection of joy there may not be in

4782.86.text:
any festivity. But enough of this: I will
govern as best I may." Then, as was the wont,

4791.00.text:
he sent for the seneschal, and gave him particular
instruction how to order matters during the

4796.64.text:
term of his sovereignty, which done, he said:
"Noble ladies, such and so diverse has been

4804.66.text:
our discourse of the ways of men and their
various fortunes, that but for the visit that

4810.31.text:
we had a while ago from Madam Licisca, who
by what she said has furnished me with matter

4816.31.text:
of discourse for to-morrow, I doubt I had
been not a little put to it to find a theme.

4823.21.text:
You heard how she said that there was not
a woman in her neighbourhood whose husband

4828.45.text:
had her virginity; adding that well she knew
how many and what manner of tricks they, after

4835.09.text:
marriage, played their husbands. The first
count we may well leave to the girls whom

4840.64.text:
it concerns; the second, methinks, should
prove a diverting topic: wherefore I ordain

4846.92.text:
that, taking our cue from Madam Licisca, we
discourse to-morrow of the tricks that, either

4853.56.text:
for love or for their deliverance from peril,
ladies have heretofore played their husbands,

4860.12.text:
and whether they were by the said husbands
detected or no." To discourse of such a topic

4867.29.text:
some of the ladies deemed unmeet for them,
and besought the king to find another theme.

4873.69.text:
But the king made answer: "Ladies, what manner
of theme I have prescribed I know as well

4879.60.text:
as you, nor was I to be diverted from prescribing
it by that which you now think to declare

4886.31.text:
unto me, for I wot the times are such that,
so only men and women have a care to do nought

4893.02.text:
that is unseemly, 'tis allowable to them to
discourse of what they please. For in sooth,

4900.34.text:
as you must know, so out of joint are the
times that the judges have deserted the judgment-seat,

4907.44.text:
the laws are silent, and ample licence to
preserve his life as best he may is accorded

4913.03.text:
to each and all. Wherefore, if you are somewhat
less strict of speech than is your wont, not

4920.27.text:
that aught unseemly in act may follow, but
that you may afford solace to yourselves and

4925.21.text:
others, I see not how you can be open to reasonable
censure on the part of any. Furthermore, nought

4933.08.text:
that has been said from the first day to the
present moment has, methinks, in any degree

4938.55.text:
sullied the immaculate honour of your company,
nor, God helping us, shall aught ever sully

4946.21.text:
it. Besides, who is there that knows not the
quality of your honour? which were proof,

4952.94.text:
I make no doubt, against not only the seductive
influence of diverting discourse, but even

4959.16.text:
the terror of death. And, to tell you the
truth, whoso wist that you refused to discourse

4965.57.text:
of these light matters for a while, would
be apt to suspect that 'twas but for that

4970.96.text:
you had yourselves erred in like sort. And
truly a goodly honour would you confer upon

4977.14.text:
me, obedient as I have ever been to you, if
after making me your king and your lawgiver,

4983.08.text:
you were to refuse to discourse of the theme
which I prescribe. Away, then, with this scruple

4989.82.text:
fitter for low minds than yours, and let each
study how she may give us a goodly story,

5000.08.text:
So spake the king, and the ladies, hearkening,
said that, even as he would, so it should

5006.67.text:
be: whereupon he gave all leave to do as they
might be severally minded until the supper-hour.

5014.12.text:
The sun was still quite high in the heaven,
for they had not enlarged in their discourse:

5020.48.text:
wherefore, Dioneo with the other gallants
being set to play at dice, Elisa called the

5025.60.text:
other ladies apart, and said: "There is a
nook hard by this place, where I think none
