5032.06.text:
of you has ever been: 'tis called the Ladies'
Vale: whither, ever since we have been here,

5039.02.text:
I have desired to take you, but time meet
I have not found until today, when the sun

5044.71.text:
is still so high: if, then, you are minded
to visit it, I have no manner of doubt that,

5050.87.text:
when you are there, you will be very glad
you came." The ladies answered that they were

5057.53.text:
ready, and so, saying nought to the young
men, they summoned one of their maids, and

5062.06.text:
set forth; nor had they gone much more than
a mile, when they arrived at the Vale of Ladies.

5068.69.text:
They entered it by a very strait gorge, through
which there issued a rivulet, clear as crystal,

5075.56.text:
and a sight, than which nought more fair and
pleasant, especially at that time when the

5081.20.text:
heat was great, could be imagined, met their
eyes. Within the valley, as one of them afterwards

5087.44.text:
told me, was a plain about half-a-mile in
circumference, and so exactly circular that

5094.71.text:
it might have been fashioned according to
the compass, though it seemed a work of Nature's

5099.58.text:
art, not man's: 'twas girdled about by six
hills of no great height, each crowned with

5106.48.text:
a palace that shewed as a goodly little castle.
The slopes of the hills were graduated from

5112.48.text:
summit to base after the manner of the successive
tiers, ever abridging their circle, that we

5119.71.text:
see in our theatres; and as many as fronted
the southern rays were all planted so close

5126.19.text:
with vines, olives, almond-trees, cherry-trees,
fig-trees and other fruit-bearing trees not

5132.16.text:
a few, that there was not a hand's-breadth
of vacant space. Those that fronted the north

5139.23.text:
were in like manner covered with copses of
oak saplings, ashes and other trees, as green

5145.46.text:
and straight as might be. Besides which, the
plain, which was shut in on all sides save

5152.06.text:
that on which the ladies had entered, was
full of firs, cypresses, and bay-trees, with

5158.39.text:
here and there a pine, in order and symmetry
so meet and excellent as had they been planted

5164.54.text:
by an artist, the best that might be found
in that kind; wherethrough, even when the

5171.10.text:
sun was in the zenith, scarce a ray of light
might reach the ground, which was all one

5177.00.text:
lawn of the finest turf, pranked with the
hyacinth and divers other flowers. Add to

5184.30.text:
which—nor was there aught there more delightsome—a
rivulet that, issuing from one of the gorges

5190.08.text:
between two of the hills, descended over ledges
of living rock, making, as it fell, a murmur

5197.59.text:
most gratifying to the ear, and, seen from
a distance, shewed as a spray of finest, powdered

5205.25.text:
quick-silver, and no sooner reached the little
plain, than 'twas gathered into a tiny channel,

5210.79.text:
by which it sped with great velocity to the
middle of the plain, where it formed a diminutive

5217.57.text:
lake, like the fishponds that townsfolk sometimes
make in their gardens, when they have occasion

5223.69.text:
for them. The lake was not so deep but that
a man might stand therein with his breast

5229.77.text:
above the water; and so clear, so pellucid
was the water that the bottom, which was of

5236.33.text:
the finest gravel, shewed so distinct, that
one, had he wished, who had nought better

5241.94.text:
to do, might have counted the stones. Nor
was it only the bottom that was to be seen,

5249.26.text:
but such a multitude of fishes, glancing to
and fro, as was at once a delight and a marvel

5255.15.text:
to behold. Bank it had none, but its margin
was the lawn, to which it imparted a goodlier

5262.05.text:
freshness. So much of the water as it might
not contain was received by another tiny channel,

5268.83.text:
through which, issuing from the vale, it glided
swiftly to the plain below.

5275.33.text:
To which pleasaunce the damsels being come
surveyed it with roving glance, and finding

5281.59.text:
it commendable, and marking the lake in front
of them, did, as 'twas very hot, and they

5287.48.text:
deemed themselves secure from observation,
resolve to take a bath. So, having bidden

5293.53.text:
their maid wait and keep watch over the access
to the vale, and give them warning, if haply

5299.34.text:
any should approach it, they all seven undressed
and got into the water, which to the whiteness

5305.86.text:
of their flesh was even such a veil as fine
glass is to the vermeil of the rose. They,

5313.20.text:
being thus in the water, the clearness of
which was thereby in no wise affected, did

5318.94.text:
presently begin to go hither and thither after
the fish, which had much ado where to bestow

5324.65.text:
themselves so as to escape out of their hands.
In which diversion they spent some time, and

5332.02.text:
caught a few, and then they hied them out
of the water and dressed them again, and bethinking

5337.69.text:
them that 'twas time to return to the palace,
they began slowly sauntering thither, dilating

5344.59.text:
much as they went upon the beauty of the place,
albeit they could not extol it more than they

5350.51.text:
had already done. 'Twas still quite early
when they reached the palace, so that they

5356.53.text:
found the gallants yet at play where they
had left them. To whom quoth Pampinea with

5362.36.text:
a smile: "We have stolen a march upon you
to-day." "So,"replied Dioneo, "'tis with you

5369.67.text:
do first and say after?" "Ay, my lord," returned
Pampinea, and told him at large whence they

5376.52.text:
came, and what the place was like, and how
far 'twas off, and what they had done. What

5382.73.text:
she said of the beauty of the spot begat in
the king a desire to see it: wherefore he

5387.22.text:
straightway ordered supper, whereof when all
had gaily partaken, the three gallants parted

5396.11.text:
from the ladies and hied them with their servants
to the vale, where none of them had ever been

5402.26.text:
before, and, having marked all its beauties,
extolled it as scarce to be matched in all

5407.44.text:
the world. Then, as the hour was very late,
they did but bathe, and as soon as they had

5415.05.text:
resumed their clothes, returned to the ladies,
whom they found dancing a carol to an air

5420.61.text:
that Fiammetta sang, which done, they conversed
of the Ladies' Vale, waxing eloquent in praise

5427.86.text:
thereof: insomuch that the king called the
seneschal, and bade him have some beds made

5434.83.text:
ready and carried thither on the morrow, that
any that were so minded might there take their

5442.36.text:
siesta. He then had lights and wine and comfits
brought; and when they had taken a slight

5448.14.text:
refection, he bade all address them to the
dance. So at his behest Pamfilo led a dance,

5455.90.text:
and then the king, turning with gracious mien
to Elisa: "Fair damsel," quoth he, "'twas

5463.08.text:
thou to-day didst me this honour of the crown;
and 'tis my will that thine to-night be the

5469.31.text:
honour or the song; wherefore sing us whatsoever
thou hast most lief." "That gladly will I,"

5477.71.text:
replied Elisa smiling; and thus with dulcet
voice began:

5482.08.text:
If of thy talons, Love, be quit I may,
I deem it scarce can be

5488.67.text:
But other fangs I may elude for aye.
Service I took with thee, a tender maid,

5494.37.text:
In thy war thinking perfect peace to find,
And all my arms upon the ground I laid,

5500.80.text:
Yielding myself to thee with trustful mind:
Thou, harpy-tyrant, whom no faith may bind,

5508.02.text:
Eftsoons didst swoop on me,
And with thy cruel claws mad'st me thy prey.

5513.48.text:
Then thy poor captive, bound with many a chain,
Thou tookst, and gav'st to him, whom fate

5521.18.text:
did call
Hither my death to be; for that in pain

5524.70.text:
And bitter tears I waste away, his thrall:
Nor heave I e'er a sigh, or tear let fall,

5531.35.text:
So harsh a lord is he,
That him inclines a jot my grief to allay.

5536.38.text:
My prayers upon the idle air are spent:
He hears not, will not hear; wherefore in

5542.40.text:
vain
The more each hour my soul doth her torment;

5546.30.text:
Nor may I die, albeit to die were gain.
Ah! Lord, have pity of my bitter pain!

5552.78.text:
Help have I none but thee;
Then take and bind and at my feet him lay.

5559.21.text:
But if thou wilt not, do my soul but loose
From hope, that her still binds with triple

5564.95.text:
chain.
Sure, O my Lord, this prayer thou'lt not refuse:

5570.15.text:
The which so thou to grant me do but deign,
I look my wonted beauty to regain,

5575.45.text:
And banish misery
With roses white and red bedecked and gay.

5584.40.text:
So with a most piteous sigh ended Elisa her
song, whereat all wondered exceedingly, nor

5591.21.text:
might any conjecture wherefore she so sang.
But the king, who was in a jolly humour, sent

5598.01.text:
for Tindaro, and bade him out with his cornemuse,
and caused them tread many a measure thereto,

5605.54.text:
until, no small part of the night being thus
spent, he gave leave to all to betake them

5613.98.text: End of Conclusion of Day Six
